title: Physical pendulums - uniform bar on distant planet

content.question: Near the surface of a distant planet, a physical pendulum made from a uniform bar of length <math alttext="L sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> exhibits small-angle oscillations about a pivot located at the top end of the bar, as shown in the figure. The planet has <math alttext="the fraction 1 over 40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>40</mn></mfrac></math> the mass and <math alttext="one fifth" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> the radius of Earth. The bar has mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 0 equals one third uppercase M sub 0, end sub, L sub 0, end sub, squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msup><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></msup></math> about the pivot axis. Which of the following differential equations describes the pendulum’s motion, where <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math> is the acceleration of gravity on Earth? The pendulum angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> is taken relative to the vertical.
